column4: sudo update-grub  # pastebin if it errors
if it errors do what foxwoods said   ^
just copy paste it to the terminal
can you walk me thru what just happend with that? everything installed fine no errors

sudo mv `which update-grub` . ;sudo dpkg --configure -a  #  the which command will find the exact path to the update-grub script  the entire command will move the update-grub script out of your path into your pwd    surely the rest is self explainitory.
thank you for the explanation as well.. I really appreciate it
you should probably run   sudo apt-get install -f  # just to make sure the package database is sain.
nothing to install.. looks good.. thanks again
quick question while we are talking kernel's.. whats the best way to remove kernel images from /boot? will StartUP Manager do this by selecting "limit kernels"?
best way "imo" is to use the package manager.  apt-get remove linux-image-$VERSION_HERE
